Dear Rush!)rook Williams, Thank you for your letter No.F.P.2009/1, of the 2nd November regarding the incidence of the cost of wireless sets for officials in the Persian Gulf area. The attitude of the Government of India is that the cost of these sets should be considered as an Imperial charge and be borne by His Majesty’s Government. May we now definitely inform them that His Majesty’s Government agree to bear the charge? As to arrangements for the supply of the sets we feel no doubt whatever that the sets which are purchasable in the Persian Gulf, were acquired locally without delay on receipt of the Government of India’s authority at the end of August. In the circumstances we think there is no need to call on the assistance of the Communications Department of the Foreign Office. Yours sincerely Pr^ r'e sor I.,F. Rushbro ok-Wi 11 i ams, (Sgd.) physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 31; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file concerns supply of wireless receiving sets for Political Agencies in the Persian Gulf.The file contains correspondence between the Government of India, HM Ministry of Information, the India Office, and the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf.
